section.title: for, since and ago and Present perfect continuous
section.sectiontitle: We use for and since with the Present perfect simple and continuous.
section.text1a: I've had this car for fifteen years.
section.text2a: She's been working since seven o'clock this morning.
section.sectiontitle2: We use ago with the Past simple.

section.title: for, since and ago and Present perfect continuous
section.sectiontitle: The Present perfect continuous is similar to the Present perfect simple. We use the Present perfect continuous if we want to emphasis that the action is long or repeated.
section.text1: to emphasise that the action is long:
section.text1a: We've been waiting here since eight o'clock!
section.text2: to emphasise that the action is repeated:
section.text2a: She's been trying to pass her driving test for years.
section.sectiontitle2: We use the Present perfect continuous if we want to emphasis that the action is in progress/not complete or when the action is temporary:
section.text3a: I've been painting the bathroom all morning.
section.text4a: He's been working in a bar this summer.

section.title: for, since and ago and Present perfect continuous
section.sectiontitle: In the positive we use have/has + been + verb + -ing. In the negative, we use have/has + not + been + verb + -ing.
section.text1a: They've been helping me with my computer.
section.sectiontitle2: In the question, we use have/has + subject + been + verb + -ing.
section.text3a: Has she been using the computer? Yes, she has.
section.text4a: Have they been waiting long? No, they haven't.
